description.text: EDIT: Updated the bracket slightly. Lengthened it by 1mm to accommodate a washer between the coupler and the bearing, and widened it slightly for better alignment with the stepper motor screws. This is an update to my Z support for the Prusa Mendel I2. Unlike the previous version, these should fit all I2 Prusas without any modification to the source model. I have a video on YouTube that covers the design and, although a bit long, I cover a few things about assembling this that will save you some time and make things go together easy. I think something like this should be included in the original design, Z creep is a problem that is completely solved by this. YouTube video linked below. If you build this for your printer, let me know how it works for you and/or post a pic here under the "I made one" area. http://youtu.be/Ei5YT3ON4P8

comments.text: I've been printing for awhile now with these installed and have not had to re-adjust my Z endstop or re-level the bed once.

UPDATE We printed this on an UP!, and it's lovely! I think these is a solid base design for a case. Now, it needs to be interesting, something better than what you can buy on a shelf. Hellooooo, meshmixer! I do like that an iphone case is something everyone recognizes, and pretty much anybody can pop out of a printer and into their lives. Hooray!

First off, this is a work in progress.  I brought my TOM to thanksgiving, and the first thing my relatives wanted to print was an iphone case.  Sadly, I lost a wire on my heating cartridge mid-print, so until my new cartridge comes in next week, I can't say for certain that it works.  
That being said, here's a case for the iphone 4s.  It's a two-piece design with a butterfly to hold everything together.  It's kinda picky about the orientation you print it in, so I put everything together in the friendliest orientation.
Inventor files are included, in case you want to adjust the design
Suggestions are welcome!
print and slide over your phone!

comments.author: SvenEDT

comments.text: It should be scaled properly--at least, I've printed a bunch of these designs and had them fit.  One thing I've noticed is that my makerbot TOM leaves a slightly wavy sidewall when I'm printing at 35mm/s, and that can make it too tight to fit.  Your results may vary, but if it's real close, try scaling it by a couple percent, or slowing down the print may give you a better fit.

author: bayart

title: AC PrintrBot LC v2 X Bridge To Bridge Support

description.text:
I was finding myself having to re-tighten the X belt quite frequently on my PrintrBot LC v2, I tried upgrading to a higher quality belt with less stretch, but that only helped a little,. After looking at the design of the two bridges, I realized that mechanically what you have here is a compression bow since the belt is off set from the carriage rods. In this you have two problems, one the bot is made of wood, wood warps even when not under tension, and I could see it with the naked eye, a definite bowing of the two bridges. The second problem this generates is that the movement of the X carriage itself is tugging on the "bow" ends whenever acceleration happens along the "string"(belt) of the bow. This tugs back and forth on the two "bow" ends during printing causing little variances in the warp of the two bridges towards the belt especially at higher movement speeds. (grab a bow and pull on the string along the strings length and watch one end of the bow bend toward the center of the string and the other end of the bow loosen a bit and "de-flex" this is happening a little every time the print head accelerates,. Causing what I can only think to describe as a warble in the print finish especially at corners where acceleration shifts. I neglected to research otherwise I would have noted that others had made various widgets to tackle this, and a chat with a local printer expert let me know that the original PrinterBot had a wood plank to help fight the bow,. (No idea why they decided to remove it in the LC, it's quite needed). Regardless I had already started working on my solution to the problem and wanted to finish what I had started. So while this is by no means an original fix it's my take on the fix,. Four parts (two printed): The shoulder: Mounts behind the right bridge, Requires a 1 inch 6-32 screw, and a 6-32 square nut, 4 1.25 inch 6-32 screws (you will need to be able to cut/grind one of them to be flush with the nut), and 4 6-32 bolts. For strength & rigidity I recommend 2-3 parameters with 2 top 2 bottom solid layers. PLA is strong enough, though ABS would likely be better. The Claw: Snaps in around the X motor, can be left loose, but there are also holes in the design to tighten the ends of the claw together with a zip tie if you wish. Two walls in all directions is plenty strong on this part. The Rod: this can be just about any 1/4 inch diameter rod material, aluminum, carbon fiber, fiberglass, etc,. Though I would caution against wood for hopefully obvious reasons, of course wood would still be better than nothing. I choose 1/4 carbon fiber rod as its strong, light, ridged, and at my hobby shop 1/4 is the cheapest size in the ball park of what I was looking for. The Mini Nuts: because the X belt tension thumb screws take up some space behind the right bridge when the carriage is all the way to the right and the "Shoulder" takes up some of this space you may need to change the wooden thumb screws to smaller profile plastic ones (also provided),. Though this is a good thing for another reason at least on the LC, move your carriage all the way to the left,. Look at the bottom of the bottom most thumb screw,. It's likely rubbing on the belt,.. bad,. These new mini nuts solve both problems. They will work with the stock hardware, though I suggest adding rubber washers just under the new mini nuts to keep them from loosening on their own from back and forth vibration. You will have to disassemble a portion of your right bridge to install the shoulder, though I found it fairly easy to do especially with a power screw driver. The screw sticking out of the back of the bridge that's towards the top and closest to the extruder will need to be made flush with its nut to not impact the movement of the carriage. Do cut this prior to installation as the dremmel will heat the bolt plenty hot enough to scotch/damage wood. The claw just uses compression to be held in place,. Push it on from the side of the motor, it should flex just enough and then snap on. Be careful of the wires that may be just under the motor. Push the 1/4 inch rod though the shoulder hole then into the claw hole. Add the square nut and 6-32 bolt to the shoulder.
Now I am playing with different ways of installing this, but so far, I have found that if I loosen up the belt, loosen up the two bridge plates that hold the big X rods in place, and then try to balance everything out with a caliper I can then tighten down the X rods, tighten down the new shoulder bolt while gently pushing the carbon rod towards the motor just a hair. And then last, tighten the belt, things get really, really smooth all of a sudden. At this time I have chosen not to epoxy the new support rod at the motor claw, and iv also not zip tied the motor claw, though the holes are there to do that if you wish. So far this loose but linearly firm system is working wonders on my print quality. Though I am considering putting some kind of foam or thin padding between the motor and claw as there is a new harmonic signature coming out of the hollow carbon fiber rod,. For now im finding it somewhat novel to have this new noise, down the line ill likely remove it by lessening the possible vibrations from the loose claw either by zip tie or padding. WARNING: I have not tested the Shoulder with the old wooden thumb screws, I fixed the belt rubbing first then designed the shoulder, I tried to give as much room as possible for the original bulky thumb screws, but I have not yet confirmed that they would not hit something on the shoulder if the carriage was all the way to the right (please let me know the results if you test this). If your dialed in right, both printable parts should print just fine without support, even with the shoulder having a fairly large bridge to do (see photos)..

title: 3D printed - International Woman's Day "pin" for buttonhole - "Venus Symbol"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is small piece that can be worn in an empty button hole to show support for Women's Rights and other Women related causes.

If you uses these please share your Make's and uses with us! Thanks and enjoy.

Two Versions:

  1. With a helper disk- (I've added a small 0.2mm disk under the "button" part of the print to eliminate the need for a raft. With just supports on this should print just fine. )
  2. Without a disk.

author: Malikigh

description.text:
This is a parametrized pool nose pinch!
We tested them and they work absolutely fine. Can be a little hard to find the transparent ones in the pool and I don't know how long they will last, but you can always print some more :)
The scad file includes a 4x2 grid with different sizes nose clamps, so you can work out which one works best for you.

Print a couple of clamps and find the right size and spring strength.
You can change the spring strength by changing the diameter of the bridge. I printed them with PLA, and found that PLA is way to hard to be clamped on your nose. Coating the cushions with hot glue or applying some heat-shrink tubing makes them a lot more comfortable to wear.

comments.author: Juggala

comments.text: Did that fix the problem?
comments.author: bcrazycramer

comments.text: I'm not going to change Repetier Host to inches. I print all my stuff from Thingiverse.com in millimeters. Can you add a wrench in millimeters?
comments.author: Juggala

comments.text: You just change the import units for the one model u are importing. It takes 2 sec. Or if u want u can scale by a factor of 25.4. You really need to learn how to do both as people from all over the world contribute to Thingiverse.
comments.author: bcrazycramer

comments.text: I will just scale is by 25.4. You may want to add that comment on your Thing Details from now on if you are going to put it out in inches.
comments.author: Juggala

comments.text: That model has been up for about 2 years you're the only person that has had a problem converting millimeters to inches most Americans already know how to do that since everything we do here is already in inches. It is a universal standard conversion that can be easily Googled. And also most professional 3D printing software has an auto conversion that you might want to look into since you seem to have problems. I recommend simplify3d is far superior to the free Repetier software.

title: Gas pipe key sleeve replacement part

description.text:
I don't know if anyone else will ever need this, but I'm posting it just in case with the sketchup file included.
Basically I had a metal sleeve that fits into a hole in the floor in which the gas valve sits for turning on the fireplace with a key.
My little boys like to reach in a pick up that chunk of metal. And they are at an age (1.5) where they like to throw things.
So I printed a plastic version of the metal sleeve, making it much safer!
Printed great. I did .2 layer height.

title: Bowden cable clamps for Techzone Huxley.

description.text:
A pair of replacements clamps to retain your Techzone Huxley bowden cable.
There's a test system included in the scad file to verify the diameter of the tube is working before printing the whole thing.
The STL is here as an example (it fits my ptfe tube bought from the grrf). You should measure your cable external diameter and use the openscad file instead.

1) Measure the external diameter of your bowden cable. Using digital calipers is better if available. 2) Open the scad file, set "tube_dia" accordingly and set "test" to 1. 3) Print the resulting test piece and verify how it clamps on your tube.
Iterate until you're happy with the clamping. 4) Set "test" to 0 and print the actual clamps.

author: DeuxVis

description.text:
I designed a USB tidy while awaiting delivery of my Ulitmaker. This is a significant revision of that design as I am a little more knowledgeable about the 3D printing process now.
The idea was to make the bewildering array of USB to something or other cables I've somehow accumulated easy to store and find when needed.
The design is very nearly fully paramterised. Certainly it is easy to vary the number of 'slots'.

I made this in PLA. As the eight slotter is quite long it needs to be well adhered to the Scotch Blue tape so I recommend checking the zero point and levelling the bed. Also, I suggest aligning the thing along the length of one strip (if your tape is wide enough), rather than across a number of strips and the tidy is difficult to remove and this minimises the loss of tape.

description.text:
I wanted to mount a Raspberry Pi camera module inside a bird box so I could stream live pictures from the box to the internet. I documented the project here.
I thought it important that the camera was securely mounted, I did not want the camera to be knocked or become detached, since once birds move in it would not be possible to adjust to reattach it.

I therefore designed this 3D printed camera mount. It is designed to hold the Raspberry Pi camera, either the standard module or the IR version along with a 5mm IR LED held in position with a bezel. I also provided a small light baffle so the IR LED did not cause glare on the camera.

Assembly

The plug is a 3 Pin IEC320 C14 with switch link:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00F4MGRRE?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00

A 3D printed Co2 car....
yeah.

I found the process of putting together my first 3D printer without access to a workshop or another 3D printer rather straightforward, except when it came to hobbing the bolt for wade's extruder.. So I thought this might be worth sharing
You can easily put together a basic hobbing jig using just hot glue, bbq skewers and a cooking pot (or any solid surface :)

Assemble the bearings and the bolt. Glue the bearings onto the surface and add more layers of glue as the glue sets. Push the bbq skewers into the glue for some support. As soon as the glue cooled down you can start hobbing with a hand drill and a tap. The bearings are easily recovered by tearing the thing apart again.

description.text:
I tried several others, but couldn't get them to work just right with some spools I got off Amazon. The defaults here are for Jet PLA with a 32mm diameter hole.  
Note, you'll have to drill out the axle hole because of the bridge layer that retains the bearing.

"ten13th" design for the Replicator 2X was just so good I made a version for the Replicator 1 Dual. And while it isn't a big fan it does blows just where you need it.
I combined "ten13th" nozzle design with minor mod's and acetone glued it to "Fan Guard with Deflector" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:31801
I modified the nozzle to give it a larger area on the back to glue the two parts together.
Using the Fan Guard allows for easy removal without needing an allen wrench
The only problem is it blocks the hypnotic view of your creation being made. UPDATE #1
Found a problem with extra-long dual color prints. (Both Extruders HOT)
As you can see from the fifth picture, even with ABS the nozzle is too close to the hot extruders. I'm now insulating the nozzle with double sided foam tape and aluminum foil, and making sure I remove it whenever active cooling is not needed.

Using Replicator 1 Dual
Printed by RepG/Sailfish Ver 40/r22
ABS Extruder 220 / Platform 110 / Enclosed
Object Infill: 10%
Layer Height: .20
Number of shells: 1
Feedrate: 40
Travel Feedrate: 55
Print Temp: 220
Printed on glass with hairspray Glue the two halves of the nozzle together.
Important TEST fit the Fan Guard and Nozzle and mark where you want to glue them, there isn't allot of clearance.
Then glue the Fan Guard and Nozzle together.

author: HonKozaneDou

description.text:
Needed a motor mount upside down on the extrusion. I believe many need something like this for tinkering on a project.

You will need to flip and mirror for whatever corner you like the mount to be placed.

Not fitting perfectly?

In case the print is not fitting perfectly, you can widen gently without sanding (which can take long).
You need the print, 30cm of aluminium extrusion, and some boiled water.
Put one end of the extrusion into the hot water for some seconds, just enough you can burn your hand (Caution: Hot water can burn you g)
Then try to push the extrusion without much force, let the energy / warm extrusion do the work.
If this is not working, take the extrusion with the printed piece on it, and let some water rinse over the connection. Not much water flow needed, just enough to transfer the heat.
Be careful when pushing so you won't change dimensions.
When you move the extrusion through the fitting, the cold end will rapidly cool the plastic.

Self-portrait from a distorted and cropped 3D scan.  
Made on MakerBot Cupcake #169 using LAYWOO-D3 wooden filament.  
I did little finishing work to hide the 3D printed-ness of this piece, choosing to keep it rough. It fits the nature of the sculpture, and it fits the temperamental nature of the wooden material. (See how it burns at the top, as the nozzle spends more time in one area.)  
Scanned using Skanect, modified using MeshMixer, cropped and sectioned using Netfabb Studio Basic.

• __Not_Me_remeshed_subtracted.stl__ is the final version of the sculpture as a single piece

  • Section_1.stl through Section_7.stl are the pieces that I printed on my tall MakerBot Cupcake

  • Not_Me_remeshed_subtracted_slicing.fabbproject is the Netfabb Studio project file that I used to split the full sculpture into sections
    • Each section was printed iusing LAYWOO-D3 with 30% infill. Earlier tests using 10% infill (the usual on my life-scale pieces) produced top layers that sagged and collapsed. I printed with rafts enabled for better stability, then snapped off the leftover "skirts" at the edge of the sections rather than try to fully remove them. The pieces were lightly sanded at join points and glued together using Gorilla Super Glue.

author: G0dl1ke

description.text:
Inspired by Bre's Moon crater, I thought, why not the whole moon? This thing is a bump mapped sphere that uses the planetary map data/images from here:
http://www.johnstonsarchive.net/spaceart/cylmaps.html Specifically, I used this one:
http://www.johnstonsarchive.net/spaceart/moonbumpmap2.jpg I essentially used the same bump mapping technique I used on this bowl: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13991 That is, use the picture as a height map. Use that height map to displace the vertices around the sphere. At the same time, use the image to colorize the thing as well, if you want extra reality. Now came the special part. Since I had the moon in my hands, I wanted to split it open and see what it was made of, answering that age old question once and for all. So, I cracked it open, and found that it was in fact hollow! No green men, no Amazonian women, no cheese, nothing, just a void. Unlike answering the Easter Bunny question, this was quite a let down. And lastly, since I was exploring the surface using MeshLab, I finally found the man in the moon. You can see him highlighted in red smiling back at us. This has got to be great for science exploration! A bit about the .stl files. I used Banate CAD to generate the models directly. The full moon has roughly 500,000 vertices, and double that in terms of faces. The partial moon has double the number of vertices because it has to generate the 'inside' as well as the outside. Each one took about 40-50 seconds to generate on my standard issue 3 year old Phenom II based machine. The generation time has more to do with the number of vertices than any other complexities. The routines create the normals for each face, whether they're needed or not, so this time could probably be cut in half in cases where you don't really need the normals, but it would not look nice when you render. To generate any spherical thing, you would just change one line of code in the .fab file: local heightsampler = ImageSampler.new({ Filename='moonbumpmap2_720_360.png', Size = size, Resolution = res, MaxHeight=16, }) Change "Filename = '...'",
to be whatever file you so happen to want to bump map. This is the quick and dirty form of Bump/Height mapping. There are two things that should be done to improve the quality of such things. First, I'm doing a straight translation from the height map to a height value. What I should really be doing is taking an average, so you don't see such artifacting. The other thing is, for a sphere, there are better ways to apply a texture than to simply wrap the rectangle. By wrapping the rectangular image to the sphere, you lose something at the poles. I need better images which account for the spherical nature. But hay, for changing just a single line of code, this is not a bad technique.

1) Download huge model
2) Print
3) Rejoice!
Repaired .stl file After all these years, I finally repaired the .stl file using Windows 3D Builder

title: Mobius Pan & Tilt with 9gram servos
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Strong & light Pan & Tilt platform for Mobius/Run Cam, inspired by similar cheap online versions. Tilts from level though to 90deg forwards. Base fits the Bix3 FPV canopy perfectly. 50grams AUW with servos.

Printer:

Fabrikator Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30

Notes:

supports required on base and middle section only.

The upper pivot hole needed cleaning out with a 5mm drillbit on my print, otherwise everything went together with no trimming.

Redesigned with a socket turntable to be more sturdy around Panning, taking the lateral forces away from the pan servo and eliminating wobble.

Specially designed for Pan to fit the Turnigy™ TGY-R5180MG 180 Degree MG Analog Servo.
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewitem.asp?idproduct=27725

For Tilt, use a Turnigy™ TGY-50090M Analog 9g Servo
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewitem.asp?idproduct=27569

Requires
4 - 2.5x6 screws
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idproduct=6984
6 - 2x6 screws
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idproduct=6987

TinkerCAD source: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hdnFXSf5Z0x

remixed_from.author: GeoDave
remixed_from.title: Remix of Mostly Printed CNC -Add On- LEG

title: MPCNC - Parametric Tall Corner Block Remix for US & IE version

description.text:
Update 5/30/17
I added a C-525 (US) & F-525 (IE) versions for the Tall Corner Blocks. This is untested, but matches the 525 offsets between the X & Y EMT. The only variable I changed for this in the openscad files was:
EMT_Spacing = 26;

Upldate 3/10/16
I added an openscad test file for sizing the locknut recesses so you do not have to print the whole flex leg to test the size. That file name is: Test_NutSize.scad

Rev9 Update 3/9/16
After looking at this design a little closer, I decided it might be better structurally to leave the plastic vertically between the X-axis & Y-axis pipe & just drill it out at the top & bottom. You can of course change the openscad code to your liking.

I liked this design, but wanted to be able to adjust a few dimensions to mostly use the least expensive bolt length I could. I sized my corners to use either M5x75mm bolts or #10x3" bolts. The 4 vertical bolt holes are on a 17.5mm x & Y offset from center which seems to be the same as the various accessory parts used on the Totem mpcnc. I am also remixing the belt tensioning plate assembly & a top limit switch plate that I will upload in the next day or so & add a link to them here. I have included the stl files for them here for reference. I found some M5x75mm bolts that are currently $0.05 each.

http://www.mrmetric.com/Discount-Items/discounted-metric-socket-head-cap-screws/M11104.html Free shipping if your order is over $50. I found #10x3" (76.2mm long) bolts at local ACE store for $0.20 each.

For the Flex Foot, I included 3 stl file versions & 2 different openscad versions.
1st stl file is for US 3/4"EMT & #10 holes & Locknuts - Flex_Foot_ForTallCorner_No10Bolt_Rev22.stl
2nd stl file is for US 3/4"EMT & M5 holes & Locknuts - Flex_Foot_ForTallCorner_M5Bolt_Rev22.stl
(actually I made the hole size the same for M5 & #10, 6mm OD)
3rd stl file is for IE 25mm & M5 holes & locknuts - IE_Flex_Foot_ForTallCorner_M5Bolt_Rev22.stl
If you want to change the openscad files for the Flex Foot between US & IE, the only difference with the pipes is:
Cyl_ID = 23.5; //US = 23.5, IE = 25.0
Cyl_OD = 35.5; //US = 35.5, IE = 37.0.
There are several other variables you can adjust, but this should be all that is needed between IE & US version

For the Tall Corner blocks, I used 6mm thickness of plastic at the bottom & top. The spacing between both the IE & US version, I measured 27.5mm distance between center lines of pipes. The stl files I created with square corner at print surface, but you can change that to rounded if you want. My printer prints this better without the rounded overhangs. There are quite a few variables you can change in the openscad & they should be well commented. The main variable to change between US & IE version is the EMT_OD variable.

I used:
EMT_OD = 23.6; //For US
EMT_OD = 25.0; //For IE

There is an A & B version for each tall corner type. The B version is a mirror image of A for opposite sides. If you make the bottom & top thickness the same and also make the print sided corners rounded, you probably can use just an A version for all 4 corners. I made the hole in the center go all the way thru as it uses less plastic & I think it makes it stronger with the extra perimeter of plastic around the holes. I made that hole .4mm large diameter than the EMT X & Y axis pipes.

You will need to print 2 copies of the A, 2 copies of the B & 8 copies of the flex foot. I would 1st print only one tall corner & one flex foot to see how the dimensions work for you before printing all the parts.

I included stl files for US & IE version, but you may want to use the openscad files to adjust to the length bolts you want. Use the more up to date stl & openscad files of these parts from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1402584

I am still printing the parts for this upgrade, so something may change. If I have missed something here, feel free to comment.

After 1st test fit, I noticed the Y-axis limit switch is higher than the roller lock. See:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1406498 for the updated limit switch & roller Lock mod.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Makerfarm i3v 10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Notes:

I am using 40%infill for the tall corners & 60% infill for the flex feet as per the original designer, Allted recommends.

description.text:
The Hangaroo is a simple 3d-printed pouch meant to hang on the back of a laptop screen and support a portable hard drive.

Fits most portable hard drives and provides holes in the base to pass a USB cable through, saves desk space in cramped situations or in places where there are already too many things on your desk.

If you regularly need to use a laptop in less friendly environments, while traveling, sharing a desk with another machine, multiple monitors, etc., "Hangaroo" gives you a convenient and out-of-the-way spot to hang your external hard drive.

Printer:

Flashforge Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Unimportant

Infill:

20% is fine

Notes:

Resolution and infill are pretty unimportant with this item - naturally, higher resolution will yield smoother looking prints but there are no details that you're going to lose. For FDM printers, you'll definitely need supports as the hanger is unsupported in some way from pretty much any angle.

This Thing contains both the version shown in the photos and an additional, harder-to-print, latticed version. If you're hanging a device that tends to run hot, the latticed version will provide additional ventilation, though convection will probably be sufficient for most things from the original design.

If you really want the latticed version but can't deal with all the support removal and cleanup it'll probably require, I do have a fantastically overpriced version on ShapeWays (just search for Hangaroo). I'm barely making 5% on the prints over there because this is apparently absurdly large by ShapeWays standards and is thus hideously expensive. Might as well buy a gold plated one if you head over, it's barely more expensive than plastic.

remixed_from.author: StefanHH
remixed_from.title: ball and socket chain links with hole through

description.text: Well, the obvious happened. I liked StefanHH's ball and socket (5578), but was astonished to see no actual helping hands design on thingiverse, (my apology if I somehow missed an existing design). So I decided to design one.

You will need a base, here in the USA I used a 3 inch x 3/8 (inside diameter) iron pipe and a matching floor flange. They are nice and heavy. Elsewhere you may need to use different, but similar things. If the dimensions of your mount is different than the ones I used, don't despair, I have included some openscad files to help you out. I designed the pipemount and base_flange in Alibre, and have included the source files. However I also wrote a openscad file that imports the stl files, and allows anyone to create new sizes for the important holes. See the scad files for details. 
Use your favorite aligator clips. I had some from a previous project. Mine had a 4.8 mm OD tube as the back end and was a jam fit into the 5578 center hole
To attach the base_flange to the pipe mount I used 4-20x3/4 plastite self tapping screws. If you need to use different screws you should be able to change the sizes in the scad files and generate your own parts.
Print 12 of thing 5578. Print 2 base_flanges and 1 pipemount. I glued the pipemount to the pipe. Attach 10 of the 5578, 5 to each side. String a 1.75mm filament (3 mm probably fits) end-end all the way through the 10 5578 and the mount. I tensioned mine a bit. Fill the end holes with glue (I used epoxy) - don't get glue in the sockets! - The filament helps keep the assembly together. Without it it will be easy to over bend the arms and dis-engage the ball and sockets. Attach your alligator clips to the other two 5578's and snap them on. In this way you can design other holder types and replace the alligator clip with them.

author: Ecelo

description.text:
Here it is, my version of a brushless gimbal. With the addition of a brushless gimbal to your multi-rotor you can turn any run of the mill quadcopter into a professional aerial photography platform. By canceling out even the smallest attitude changes the gimbal can give truly remarkable results. This gimbal is designed around my quadcopter and will also be compatable with my tricopter in the near future. Donate Video Links:
http://vimeo.com/71358538 Update 3/27/15: I have updated the motor mounts to a more "universal" format and I have added extra support on the batter tray to keep it from sagging from the camera and motor weight. Update 2/17/14: I've added a 1/8th offset to the case, this should center up the lens on the longitudinal axis of the quadcopter, thanks Pylo. Update 11/14/13: Just uploaded a video I shot of some BASE jumping. Check it out if you are wondering about a gimbal. Update 01/27/14: Uploaded modified gimbal flies. Added a GoPro3 case as well as well as lock nuts in the arm for easier attachment (thanks Miguel for the idea).

Print and assemble the gimbal. 10% Infill is more than enough as the gimbal does not need to be incredibly strong. The gimbal uses T-motor 2208 brushless motors and a SimpleBGC by AlexMos. The software, firmware, instructions and GUI can be found at http://www.basecamelectronics.com

comments.author: dcowan

comments.text: No the KK 2.1 will not control a brushless gimbal. Those ports are designed for servos, brushless motors are a bit more complicated. You will need a controller, there are a few on the market right now. Martinez and Alexmos are the most popular I would say. Martinez is open source and Alexmos is not. I have had success with both but I would say that the Alexmos is definitely easier to setup. You will also need two brushless motors like the ones I have listed. remixed_from.author: machina
remixed_from.title: Duchamp Chess Set - Self Supporting Overhangs

description.text:
On April 21st, 2014, Scott Kildall and Bryan Cera uploaded 3D (STL) files of a set of chess pieces designed by Marcel Duchamp (1918) onto Thingiverse. Unfortunately, the project struck a nerve with the Duchamp Estate, who subsequently presented Kildal and Cera with a cease and desist letter, alleging intellectual property infringement. As the pieces were designed by Duchamp himself, and not appropriated as a readymade, they are claimed under the domain of French copyright law (although legal jurisdiction is uncertain- If the stl. files are downloaded from a U.S. server, is the printer protected under U.S. copyright law, or does the global nature of a website like Thingiverse negate site-contingent legal protection?)
Thus the inspiration for this remix was twofold:
I. The increasing popularity- in a contemporary art context- for legally enforced boundaries to be drawn around something so amorphous as an idea (intellectual property).
II. The fundamental nature of 3D printing community platforms like Thingiverse, which invite idea sharing and remediation.
These molds of the Duchamp chess pieces aim to define the limits of intellectual property law by occupying what would be the adjacent (negative) space to the legally protected volume of Duchamp's design. They also reflect the collaborative ethos of Thingiverse in that they allow for third party individuals to cast from the molds, as the title Ready-to-be-Made suggests.

A better mounting foot than the rather poorly conceived mounting scheme that MakerBot ships with their MK7 kit. It cuts the number of things that need to be aligned at once from four to two. I am anticipating removing the MK7 a bit, as I plan to build my own second extruder.

Print two feet. Remove the MK7. Press the nuts into the hex holes. Press the feet onto the MK7 mounting plates. Enjoy the much easier way to remove and attach your MK7 as you go from one to two extruders, or mod it so you can change filaments easier. See the photos for any more details. 
I designed this in Alibre and have included the source file, but this is such a special purpose part I don't see much room for modifications.

comments.text: You should be getting better quality prints from your ToM and MK7, use SF40 and above and check your filament diameter with calipers. You can eliminate warp by ditching the ABP. It's a nice idea but the belt material warps under heat. Use Kapton tape on an aluminum heat spreader and NEVER have a warped print! Love this idea, printing it shortly!

comments.text: Thanks for the input, this was one of my first prints with the MK7. Whats the difference between SF40+ and SF35? I agree with your ABP comments, I have a steel foil belt, which really helps, but still isn't perfect. I have used a kaptoned plate, I just screw it down on top of the belt and disconnect the APB gearmotor. However I'm spoiled with the auto eject and sequential build capabilities of the ABP - the parts are really hard to get off!  The warping is annoying, but not a show stopper for me

author: into3D

title: Any Position Universal Size Filament Spool Holder Turntable

description.text:
I just built a very nice SeeMeCNC Rostock Max v2 printer and wanted to create an universal turntable style filament spool holder that spins smoothly.

Aside from the printed parts all you need is 1 skateboard bearing.

I used this awesome thing to help with the design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647

Enjoy! Let me know what you think.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3 mm

Infill:

cone base plate 100% all others 30%

Notes:

I used ABS

1) Grab 1 skateboard bearing insert into filament spool base plate.
2) Remove the 1mm thick disk from both cones.
3) Glue/bond 1 cone and nut combo to cone base plate (there is no need to glue the nut into cone).
4) Insert cone assembly into skateboard bearing (press further in for desired spinning resistance)
5) Mount.
6) Thread shaft into cone assembly.
7) Place filament spool on turntable.
8) Glue/bond the second nut into the second cone.
9) Thread the cone assembly on shaft.

I will also then design the top part of the table that will be a throw away part The table was designed to be used with this o-ring cord http://www.smallparts.com.au/store/item/orc00150n70/. I inserted the cord and it seems to fit nicely. There isn't too much of the cord sticking out of the groove so I don't think there will be leaks and I think it won't bend the top table. comments.text: I haven't tried it yet, I am going to redesign it.  The idea was to have a flexible pipe attached to the machine and to the plate and then suck the air out like that.  Problem is uncle Newton came to me in a dream and he said "To every action there is always an equal and opposite reaction" so what might happen is the motor will try to move the table one way and the vacuum will pull it another way.  It might put alot of strain on the motor.  Also having the suction on the one side will unbalance the bearings and wear them out or the rods

description.text:
Found here are all the files for printing a one pound "antweight" combat robot. These files are specifically for the all plastic version, used in the 3d printing friendly "Plastic Ant" class our local robot fighting club has started. For that version, I use eSun PLA Pro which is perfect for this sort of thing. I also have a standard ant version with a metal blade and I used nylon instead of PLA Pro for the front legs and wheel guards (nylon is prohibited in the Plastic Ant class.) The Nylon version is basically the same, though some sort of hub for a metal weapon would need to be crafted. The nylon holds up surprisingly well to even the most dangerous ant weapons. I've yet to try PLA Pro against normal ants, but I suspect it'll be insufficient to handle direct hits.

Filament: ESun PLA Pro (NOT standard PLA), or Taulman Bridge Nylon for front legs and wheel guards.
Infill: 60%
Outside Perimeter: 5mm

Additional Parts:

For non-plastic, a blade of some sort. A sawblade will do, but there are better options.
2x 2" GWS Foam Wheels (hub removed) - http://www3.towerhobbies.com/cgi-bin/wti0001p?&I=LXHJA2&P=FR&gclid=CIHl2pHNsssCFRSUfgodaRcA8w
1x Brushless outrunner, 28mm diameter -http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__65236__D2822_14_Brushless_Outrunner_1450kv_AR_Warehouse_.html?strSearch=d2822
2x speed controllers (ESCs) for the gear motors - http://www.fingertechrobotics.com/proddetail.php?prod=ft-tinyESCv2)
1x brushless speed controller for the weapon motor - http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__58265__Flycolor_20_Amp_Multi_rotor_ESC_4_6S_Opto.html?strSearch=flycolor
1x 11.1v 250mah LiPo battery - http://www.motionrc.com/admiral-250mah-3s-11-1v-30c-lipo-battery/
1x Receiver - http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__61211__OrangeRx_R410X_DSMX_Compatible_4Ch_6CH_PWM_CPPM_2_4Ghz_Receiver_.html
2x Micro Gearmotos http://www.robotmarketplace.com/products/0-PL998.html (this is the example, but they can be found for far cheaper on ebay)

Lots and lots of 4-40 machine screws (asst lengths) and nuts

With a bright light it is sometimes possible to see the conductive track loops forming the antenna coil. A cut anywhere along this track disables the antenna. A 1 mm hole at the spot indicated is most likely to produce the desired effect. This is how my card looks after a successful operation punch. Yes! the contact chip still works but the wireless functionality is dead.

I had good luck printing a key for a spare Kwikset lock I had lying around the house so I decided to take it one step further and make a working key that fits in my Keyport Slide 2.0 (also compatible with 1.0) I designed this with tinkercad using measurements taken from the original part with a cheap digital caliper. It has opened the lock over 20 times now with no issues. It has actually gotten smoother.
I recommend printing this at maximum layer height, 100% infill, and a higher than average temperature to stiffen the PLA. 240C Yielded good results on my R2

title: Tape Dispenser 3" Wide x 3" I.D.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Tape dispenser for 3-inch wide blue painter's tape. Improved Dec 24, 2013. Fully 3D printable without supports. New improved version has base parts with holes for mounting screws and they clip over the bottom of the side parts (one near the front, one near the back) for sturdy mounting to a bench. The first photo shows the original version that had base parts with no holes (I drilled them to put screws through to the work bench) and relied on glue to bond them to the sides, but the force required to pull tape off the spool was too much and the glue joints kept failing. This revision fixes that by having the bases clamp over the horizontal members at the bottom of the sides. The blade still uses super glue to hold it in place -- more about the blade in the instructions. A printable serrated blade can be found at
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2329277 Second photo added 13MAR2014 showing the new bases that clamp over the bottom of the sides.

I printed in PLA with 0.25mm layers, 20% fill, 2 skins. Print these files to make a complete set of parts:
2 each: 3inTD-Side.stl (Makes 1 Side)
1 each: 3inTD-Hub.stl (Makes 1 Hub)
1 each: BasesBlade&Pins.stl (Makes 2 Bases, 1 Blade & 2 Pins) Or if you want to print the parts separately, these files are also supplied:
3inTD-BaseX2.stl (Makes 2 Bases)
3inTD-Base.stl (Makes 1 Base)
3inTD-Blade.stl (Makes 1 Blade)
3inTD-PinX2.stl (Makes 2 Pins) SolidWorks Files Included:
3inTD-Base.SLDPRT
3inTD-Pin.SLDPRT
3inTD-Blade.SLDPRT
3inTD-Side.SLDPRT
3inTD-Hub.SLDPRT The Blade has a beveled edge for cutting the tape. I sharpened the edge with a file and it works pretty well for cutting blue tape (see more about cutting the tape below). The blade is inserted and glued into the holes on the sides that have the same cross-section as the blade. A metal cutting edge could be added fairly easily if desired, but the PLA plastic sharpened with a file seems to be adequate as long as you get a good sharp edge on it. Ultimately, I made an aluminum blade from 1mm thick aluminum sheet, sharpened the edge, and stuck it on top of the plastic cutter part, attached with double-sided woven fiberglass carpet tape (available at hardware stores). It seems to work better than the PLA blade, as one might expect. I used super glue to attach the plastic blade to the sides where it inserts into the holes. I also used super glue to attach the pins to the hub, leaving the heads of the pins out 5mm from the hub to allow clearance for the 5mm thick sides. I found that super glue doesn't hold PLA too well, but inserting a thin layer of tissue paper material (I used a paper towel) between the mating PLA part faces and saturating with super glue makes a fairly strong bond, but it can still come apart). Use 4 each #4 x 3/4" wood screws through the countersunk holes in the two base parts to mount to the workbench or #4 or 3mm flat head machine screws and nuts for through-hole mounting. You have to learn a new way of tearing the tape. If you just try to tear it off by pulling the tape down on the cutting edge the tape won't tear cleanly, or at all. This is because blue tape is essentially stretchy crepe paper with sticky on it, and pulling it straight down just stretches it (unless you have a very sharp, serrated metal edge). To tear the tape cleanly you must grab the tape near one edge and give it sort of a 90 degree twist down, so the tape edge where the tear starts gets all the force, rather than applying force to the entire width of the tape along the blade edge. Only then can you easily start the cut at that edge, and once it starts the rest of the tear is easy. It's harder to describe than to do it, but once you get the hang of it you can do it every time in one rapid motion. I went through a couple feet of tape before I figured out the method that works every time! If you make one of these dispensers you WILL figure it out sooner or later -- like I did.

comments.text: The more I look at it, the more I want to improve it. However, I have only printed one, and it is still in use, so it has stood the test of time. I was just beginning to learn Solidworks when I designed this, and I wasn't paying much attention to printer test results that tell me how much to add or subtract for good fitting printed dimensions. I got close enough on my first (and only) print to allow me to put it together. I don't use the pins on the spindle; using a 1/4"-20 threaded rod and 2 jam nuts on each end for a spindle axle. I have been thinking about a redesign based on having used it now for close to four years, but haven't taken the time yet. It could stand improvements.

comments.text: Yes, it was designed for blue tape and the sharpened PLA blade I made was barely adequate for cutting blue tape. I added a blade made from 1/16-inch (~1mm) thick aluminum sheet cut to fit on top of the plastic blade, sharpened one edge at a 45 degree angle, and stuck on top of the plastic blade with double-sided carpet tape. But for cellotape I think you'd need a steel blade with small serrations (like on tape dispensers). It may be possible to use the serrated metal blade that comes on aluminum foil, wax paper or plastic wrap packages.

description.text:
Lithophane Test Cards are designed to help users determine the optimal print settings for 3D printed lithophanes. Variables such as filament color, opacity, slicer settings and lighting display conditions can have a dramatic effect on the appearance of the final image. The Lithophane Test Cards allows users to dial in an appropriate lithophane model height to reliably achieve the desired contrast under the final lighting setup.

Test cards are included at 3mm, 5mm or 10mm test heights. These test card can be scaled in the z-axis before slicing to fine tune the settings.

These Lithophane Test Cards were created using the Test Card image at https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Test_card.png and converted into an STL via the awesome http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/ by @MarkDurbin104
